unnormalised: Cybersecurity in India: Are You Really Safe?
normalised: Cybersecurity in India: Are You Really Safe?

unnormalised: Hey folks! Ever wondered how safe your data actually is in this digital Bharat? We’re all online these days – UPI payments, booking train tickets via IRCTC, scrolling through Insta… you name it! But with great convenience comes great risk, right? Let’s talk cybersecurity, Indian style.
normalised: Hey folks! Ever wondered how safe your data actually is in this digital Bharat? We’re all online these days – U-P-I payments, booking train tickets via I-R-C-T-C, scrolling through Insta… you name it! But with great convenience comes great risk, right? Let’s talk cybersecurity, Indian style.

unnormalised: First off, phishing scams are rampant. You get that email from “SBI” asking you to update your KYC? Or that SMS claiming you’ve won a Tata Motors car? Beware! These guys are good. They’ll use anything – even a fake Aadhaar link – to steal your info. Never click on suspicious links, even if they look legit. Call the actual bank or company to verify. Don't prepone your safety!
normalised: First off, phishing scams are rampant. You get that email from “S-B-I” asking you to update your K-Y-C? Or that S-M-S claiming you’ve won a Tata Motors car? Beware! These guys are good. They’ll use anything – even a fake Aadhaar link – to steal your info. Never click on suspicious links, even if they look legit. Call the actual bank or company to verify. Don't prepone your safety!

unnormalised: Then there's malware. Downloading that free Bollywood movie from a shady site? Chances are, you're also downloading something nasty. Anti-virus software is a must, even on your phone. Think of it as your digital bodyguard. Keep it updated too. A good example of a trusted Antivirus is Kaspersky.

unnormalised: And what about data breaches? Remember when Air India got hacked, exposing the data of millions of passengers? Or that time 3.2 million debit cards were compromised? These things happen, and they’re terrifying. Companies need to invest more in security, and frankly, the government needs to hold them accountable. Maybe a fine of Rs. 1 crore?
normalised: And what about data breaches? Remember when Air India got hacked, exposing the data of millions of passengers? Or that time three point two million debit cards were compromised? These things happen, and they’re terrifying. Companies need to invest more in security, and frankly, the government needs to hold them accountable. Maybe a fine of rupee one crore?

unnormalised: Here's another thing: weak passwords. "Password123" or your birthday? Seriously? Use a strong, unique password for every account. Consider using a password manager. And enable two-factor authentication (2FA) wherever possible. It adds an extra layer of security, like a digital "raksha kavach".
normalised: Here's another thing: weak passwords. "Password one two three" or your birthday? Seriously? Use a strong, unique password for every account. Consider using a password manager. And enable two-factor authentication (two F-A) wherever possible. It adds an extra layer of security, like a digital "raksha kavach".

unnormalised: The government is trying to do its part, like with the CERT-In guidelines, but awareness is key. We, the users, need to be more vigilant. Teach your parents and grandparents about online safety. They are particularly vulnerable. The younger generation of India should be more responsible in this matter.

unnormalised: So, are we really safe? Not entirely. But by staying informed, being cautious, and taking basic security measures, we can significantly reduce our risk. Stay safe online, and remember, a little paranoia goes a long way. Also check for security updates from Microsoft and Apple regularly!
